alert.note: Alert for Admiralty Island; Annette Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Juneau; City and Borough of Sitka; City and Borough of Wrangell; City and Borough of Yakutat; City of Hyder; Eastern Chichagof Island; Glacier Bay; Haines Borough and Klukwan; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Municipality of Skagway; Petersburg Borough; Prince of Wales Island; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued January 11 at 11:59AM AKST by NWS Juneau
info.description: ...VERY COLD TEMPERATURES AND WIND CHILLS THIS WEEK FOLLOWED BY SNOW FOR THE WEEKEND... The first outflow event of this Winter season is ongoing. Overnight lows have been observed as low as single digits to teens over most of the panhandle with below zero readings in the extreme north. Breezy conditions in some areas are also causing wind chills down to -20 in some cases in the low elevations. Coldest temperatures are expected Friday morning with similar values as what were observed early Thursday morning. Residents are encouraged to take precautions to prevent the freezing and bursting of vulnerable plumbing both indoors and outdoors. Pets and other animals normally maintained outdoors should also be attended to as temperatures remain cold. Into this weekend, accumulating snow is expected to start. The outer coast from Yakutat to Pelican will likely start to see light snow as early as Saturday while other locations will start to see snow Saturday night or Sunday. Snow amounts could range as high as 6 to 8 inches along the NE outer coast to around 4 inches in parts of the inner channels, especially in the north, through Sunday night.
